_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Full System Mechanical Integrity Inspection by Contractor
_prev_prog_3.Description: Ammonia refrigeration system with more than 10,000 pounds subject to OSHA's PSM standard.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Michael Lewis Company (MLCO) facility has an emergency response plan in effect. The emergency response plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document. This plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1. To save lives.

2. To minimize and avoid injuries.

3. To protect the environment.

4. To minimize property damage.

MLCO maintains a Process Safety Management committee which contains members who are the emergency coordinators for the facility. The emergency response plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures for which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This plan was updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The ammonia process was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local regulations. The facility is located at 8900 W. 50th Street, McCook, IL.



The ammonia refrigeration system uses approximately 13,000 pounds of ammonia for the storage of various food products. The majority of the system is located in the engine room including vessels and compressors. The condensor is mounted on the engine room roof, and all evaporators are located in their respective cold storage rooms/areas.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The facility that MLCO occupies is new as of November, 2009. The ammonia refrigeration system installed 

was designed and constructed in accordance with ammonia refrigeration industry safety and design standards.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room or on the engine room roof. The engine room

is provided with continuous ventilation and all equipment is monitored for temperature and pressure 24 hours a day. The facility is secured and guarded at all times.



In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines. In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Start-up, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems."



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There is no reportable accident history at this facility.



EMERGENCY REPONSE PROGRAM



In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest the leak will notify a supervisor, maintenance or risk management. Under certain circumstances an alarm will sound and automatically notify the 24 hour security company who in turn will page the Facility Manager. In either event a team of at least two trained individuals will respond to the scene to assess the situation. Portable radios and an ammonia sampling meter are used for communication and air sampling. The emergency coordinators will be notified of the situation and will determine what procedures and personnel, including contractors, are necessary to remedy the problem. Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Response Plan. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Being a new facility, no changes have been identified.



END SUMMARY
